The contrast between rationality and the spirit of Dionysus has been a central theme in Western thought, particularly in philosophy and literature. The German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche explored this dichotomy in his work, “The Birth of Tragedy”, where he introduced the concepts of the Apollonian and Dionysian.
Apollonian: Represents order, logic, and rationality, named after Apollo, the Greek god of the sun, light, and knowledge. Dionysian: Represents chaos, emotion, and the irrational, named after Dionysus, the Greek god of wine, ecstasy, and revelry. Nietzsche argued that a healthy culture requires a balance between these two forces. Too much rationality (Apollonian) can lead to rigidity, sterility, and a lack of creativity, while too much Dionysian spirit can lead to chaos, destructiveness, and loss of self-control. The ideal, according to Nietzsche, is to embrace both aspects, finding a balance between reason and emotion, structure and freedom.
In modern terms, this balance might be seen as integrating analytical thinking with emotional intelligence, allowing for both structured, logical decision-making and creative, passionate expression. This integration can lead to a more holistic and fulfilling experience of life, where one is open to both the joys of rational thought and the ecstasy of Dionysian freedom.

We often say that the sun rises,
but on the moon, one would see the ‘Earth rise.’
When the frame of reference changes,
what seems natural becomes astonishing.
In the vast expanse of space and time,
our beliefs and assumptions are merely part of a larger plan.
As the stars shift and the heavens turn,
certainty is a fragile thing,
bound by the limits of our perception and time.
The truths we choose to believe in
often dissipate like mist.
In the quiet of the night, we are often struck by the thought
that perhaps what we call truth
is merely a rough draft in the Creator’s hands.

content: The so-called “I” is the sum of all past experiences—composed of the people I have met, the things I have touched, the love I have felt, and the pain I have lost myself in. All of these together form the “me” of this moment; take away even one slight of me, and I am no longer the same. Hermann Hesse’s spiritual journey of self-discovery, as portrayed in Siddhartha and other works, reflects this notion of the self as an evolving entity shaped by life’s myriad experiences. After reading these words, perhaps you will view the people you have encountered in a slightly different light—recognizing that, they together with you shape the uniqueness of you.

When you’re a kid, everything is astonishing. Everything is new. And so your brain is awake and turned on. So every second, your brain is learning something new: how the world works. And so the muscle of your brain is activated.
And as you get older and your brain has figured out the patterns of how the world works: this is how you make money; this is how you graduate school; this is how you get a mortgage; this is how you have kids… And once your brain establishes a routine, it stops.
The alertness and the fascination with how the world works go away. That’s what travel is in general - it wakes up your brain.

“Living only for the moment, turning our attention to the pleasures of the moon, the snow, the cherry blossoms and the maples, singing songs, drinking wine and diverting ourselves in just floating, floating, caring not a whit for the poverty staring us in the face, refusing to be disheartened, like a gourd floating along with the river current: this is what we call the floating world.”
From A Tale of the Floating World, by Asai Rydi, about 1665 (translated by Richard Lane)

“Political correctness” was quietly discussed at the time of the victory of “Everything Everywhere All at Once”. This view arose early when Moonlight Boy won the award that year; after all, it was another hard look at the rise of minorities.
Some people say that “political correctness” is the biggest source of antipathy for hypocrisy - a polite and friendly way to give way to smiling may follow the social identity of “good citizens,” as to the extent to which this act of kindness is due to “you” is hard to know.
But what is clear is that without the “political correctness” shield, discrimination and prejudice will only be more direct and severe. No one can retreat from the “motive” of torture.
“Judge me by my deeds not intentions”
